ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by MRI showing a 2.95 x 2.4 cm tumor on the left CP angle; consistent with unilateral tinnitus, high-frequency asymmetry, abnormal TEN test, and absent ABR Wave V.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Retrocochlear Lesion
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Initial suspicion raised by unilateral tinnitus and slight high-frequency asymmetry; strongly supported by cochlear dead regions on TEN test and absent ABR Wave V.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Subclinical Processing Abnormality
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered initially due to normal pure-tone thresholds and difficulty in noise, but ruled out by identification of the tumor.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To inspect the ear canals and tympanic membranes for visible pathology.
To assess hearing sensitivity; revealed clinically normal thresholds with slight left-sided high-frequency asymmetry.
To assess speech recognition thresholds, which aligned with pure tone averages.
To evaluate middle ear function; results were normal (Type A) bilaterally.
To assess outer hair cell function; robust emissions were present bilaterally.
To characterize the reported tinnitus; pitch-matched to 1.5 kHz in the left ear.
To assess for cochlear dead regions or neural dysfunction given the unilateral symptoms; revealed abnormalities in the left ear.
To screen for retrocochlear pathology; revealed absence of Wave V in the left ear.
Definitive imaging to confirm retrocochlear pathology; revealed a large acoustic neuroma.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presented with normal hearing sensitivity but significant functional complaints (unilateral tinnitus, difficulty in noise). While basic audiometry and OAEs were normal, slight high-frequency asymmetry prompted further investigation. The TEN test indicated neural dysfunction/dead regions, and ABR showed retrocochlear signs (absent Wave V). MRI subsequently confirmed a large left acoustic neuroma compressing the brainstem.

tests.name: Otoscopy
tests.result_summary: Clear ear canals and intact tympanic membranes bilaterally.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds bilaterally; left ear slightly worse (10-20 dB HL) than right (0-10 dB HL) at 2000, 4000, and 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs in quiet were 15 dB HL (right) and 20 dB HL (left), consistent with pure tone averages.

tests.name: TEN (Threshold Equalizing Noise) Test
tests.result_summary: Abnormal results in the left ear at 1, 1.5, 3, and 4 kHz suggesting inner hair cell/neural dysfunction; right ear normal.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear normal; Left ear showed absence of wave V at 70 dBnHL.

tests.name: MRI
tests.result_summary: Large acoustic neuroma (2.95 x 2.4 cm) on the left CP angle compressing the brainstem and VIIIth cranial nerve.

proposed_items: Referral to neurotologist for management of acoustic neuroma
Stereotactic radiosurgery (Gamma Knife) selected as treatment
counseling_actions: Explanation that the tumor is causing the difficulty in noise and tinnitus despite normal pure-tone thresholds
Discussion of management options including microsurgery, stereotactic radiation therapy, and stereotactic radiosurgery
Counseling regarding potential worsening of hearing and tinnitus post-radiation

escalation.rationale_short: Large acoustic neuroma compressing the brainstem requires specialist intervention.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing thresholds, tinnitus, and tumor response to treatment.

expected_outcome: Otoscopy: Clear ear canals and intact tympanic membranes bilaterally.
Tympanometry: Normal ear canal volumes, peak pressure, and static admittance bilaterally.
Pure-tone audiometry (Right Ear): Thresholds within normal limits at all frequencies.
Pure-tone audiometry (Left Ear): Mild sensorineural hearing loss from 1000 Hz through higher frequencies; asymmetry increased compared to initial visit.
Hearing in Noise Test (HINT): Performance within normal percentiles for both quiet and noise front conditions.
Subjective: Patient denied any worsening of tinnitus.
Functional status: Bilateral functional hearing retained; amplification device not recommended.
